Observations and investigations in the

Labrador Sea

Seaglider observations during active convection

Four of the five Seagliders deployed in the Labrador Sea observed deep convection, with well-mixed water columns down to the depth of observation (1000 m). This offers an unprecedented look at deep convection with horizontal resolution of 10 km (Frajka-Williams, Rhines, & Eriksen, 2014).

Seaglider method to extract vertical velocities

Vertical water velocity is notoriously difficult to measure, in part because it is so small. Deep convection offered a unique opportunity to investigate the velocities as estimated using a Seaglider and its hydrodynamic flight model (Frajka-Williams, Eriksen, Rhines, & Harcourt, 2011). The method is estimated to be accurate to 0.6 cm/s.

Spring bloom: from space

The Labrador Sea spring bloom has a distinct pattern: a triangle with centroid over where the 3000m isobath turns westward away from the Greenland shelf. We explain the bloom pattern in terms of haline stratification, and sources of that stratification (mean background flow and eddy transport from the West Greenland Shelf) and analyze interannual relationships between the bloom, runoff from Greenland and eddies (Frajka-Williams & Rhines, 2010).

Spring bloom: from Seagliders

Phytoplankton blooms in the Labrador Sea occur under a variety of distinct physical conditions: in terms of the sources of stratification and the structure of the bloom and hydrography (eddies, fronts and thin layers) (Frajka-Williams, Rhines, & Eriksen, 2009).

References

  1. Horizontal stratification during Deep convection in the Labrader Sea.
    (2014) Frajka-Williams, Eleanor and Rhines, Peter B. and Eriksen, Charles C.. J. Phys. Ocean., 44:220–228. doi: 10.1175/JPO-D-13-069.1. details
  2. Determining Vertical Velocities from Seaglider.
    (2011) Frajka-Williams, Eleanor and Eriksen, Charles C. and Rhines, Peter B. and Harcourt, Ramsey R.. J. Atmos. Ocean. Tech., 28:1641–1656. doi: 10.1175/2011JTECHO830.1. details
  3. Physical controls and interannual variability of the Labrador Sea spring phytoplankton bloom in distinct regions.
    (2010) Frajka-Williams, Eleanor and Rhines, Peter B.. Deep Sea Res. I, 57:541–552. doi: 10.1016/j.dsr.2010.01.003. details
  4. Physical controls and mesoscale variability in the Labrador Sea spring phytoplankton bloom observed by Seaglider.
    (2009) Frajka-Williams, Eleanor and Rhines, Peter and Eriksen, Charles. Deep Sea Res. I, 56:2144–2161. doi: 10.1016/j.dsr.2009.07.008. details

About Me

I am a lecturer in physical oceanography at the University of Southamton, England. My research interests span small-scale ocean physics to large-scale dynamics of the overturning circulation. I use observations - from ships, satellites, seagliders and moorings - as well as numerical simulations to investigate the oceans. More ›
